abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, though institutional development
            impacts, are only modest. A number of lessons address
            issues, both on the restructuring and privatization program,
            as well as on the investment component. The restructuring
            and reform program could not have been implemented without
            the full commitment of the Government, which in the absence
            of, the management of reforms and the pace of restructuring
            suffered initially. Specifically, ambitious restructuring,
            reforms, and privatization, require specialized skills which
            were lacking; however, the technical assistance component,
            and local staff willingness to acquire skills contributed to
            satisfactory outcomes. Conversely, the reform program,
            should be viewed as an integrated set of policies; however,
            financial viability and measures to mitigate adversity were
            not accorded adequate priority, thus resulting in financial
            repercussions on the utilities, risking also the
            macroeconomic stabilization program. As for privatization of
            utilities, the diverse and conflicting objectives of
            interest groups, require a policymaking Government role,
            setting priorities, particularly in implementing information
            dissemination campaigns to build an acceptance privatization
            program. The absence of it, derived in potential benefits
            remaining fairly adverse. Finally, the investment component
            should have ensured compliance with acceptable efficiency,
            and least cost-criteria, which highlights the importance of
            realistic assumptions at appraisal, basing estimates in a
            range of scenarios to accommodate potential risks.
